title: Jane Park announces she's pregnant six years on from Euromillions jackpot win
text:
Get the biggest celebs stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

She became one of Britain’s youngest Euromillions winners when she bagged £1million at 17 – but it couldn’t buy happiness.

The day Jane Park hit the jackpot with her first ever lucky dip ticket she was an office assistant sharing a bedroom with her sister in her family’s council house.

She splashed cash on luxury cars, ­designer clothes and property.

New boobs and cosmetic work on her bottom and teeth followed. Yet still she couldn’t claim to be content.

Now, six years on, Jane reveals she is expecting her first child – and finally says she has found genuine contentment.

(Image: Daily Record)

“Seeing the positive pregnancy test was more exciting than seeing the winning numbers on my lottery ticket,” she said. “It’s a crazy time but I am so happy.

Jane, wise at 23, continued: “People think ­winning the lottery is the best thing that can happen to you but this is ­something that no amount of cash could buy.

“Everybody thinks buying a flash car is exciting but in reality, for me, shopping for a pram is ten times more fulfilling.

“When you suddenly come into a lot of money you become isolated and desperate to build bonds and relationships.

“For the first time I feel like I will have someone new in my life who loves me for me and not because of my bank balance. And that is such a comforting thing.”

(Image: MediaUse.co.uk)

Jane, who lives with her mum in Edinburgh, says she is not in a relationship with the father, a friend called Barry.

“I had imagined finding a boyfriend, settling down and then having a baby, but it just didn’t work out that way,” she said.

“Barry and I originally started talking over social media and grew into friends.

“We became close and one night things naturally progressed. We are both ­committed to being parents.

“I’m grateful he works full-time and is a good person.”

Jane has struggled to find true love. Last November she even launched a website to offer a £60,000-a-year ­salary for Mr Right.

Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now

A string of high-profile ­romances with X Factor star Sam Callahan in 2017 and Dundee FC’s Jordan Piggott in 2018 crashed and burned.

Discovering her pregnancy initially made her head spin. “It was a mixture of ­excitement and fear,” she said.

“I called the father instantly while he was at work and, like me, he was really shocked.

“It took him 24 hours to get his head around it but then he called and I could tell the shock grew to nervousness, followed by excitement.

(Image: PA)

“It is all becoming more real and he’s doing everything he can to be involved.”

Three months into her pregnancy, Jane reflected on how ­impending motherhood has changed her.

“I’ve all of a sudden felt like someone with responsibility and will have to be completely unselfish and look after this little person.

“No amount of money can change the fact that my baby is coming in six months and that’s helping me to mentally prepare.”

The pregnancy ­follows a ­turbulent six years since her 2013 win.

The new teenage millionaire quit her £8-an-hour job, spent two months in Magaluf and bought a chihuahua and a three-bedroom home.

She splashed out on a £25,000 BMW, a £17,000 VW Beetle and a ­customised Range Rover for £18,000.

(Image: MediaUse.co.uk)

Jane had a Brazilian bum lift in Turkey – which was botched – and a £50,000 makeover, including breast enhancement. She recalled: “I ­ struggled with feeling isolated and scared.

I wrongly publicised my win so as a 17-year-old girl living in a house alone for the first time it was terrifying knowing that everyone knew I was a millionaire.

“I moved back into my family home within a couple of months and rented out my properties. It made me different to everyone of my age. I felt like I lost my place in the world.”

In May she revealed how she was selling £50 topless photos online and donating proceeds to charity – but insisted she felt “empowered” and “like Robin Hood”.

(Image: Daily Record)

Jane said: “I have always been open about spending on cosmetic procedures. It came from wanting to be accepted and desirable in a way but also because I have had people be really unkind about my looks since I have been in the public eye.

“I know my body will change as I become a mum but suddenly superficial things like that don’t seem as ­important to me now. As long as I have a happy and healthy baby I don’t mind the way I look.”

Jane – who has vowed to be a “glam” mum – went on: “Winning the lottery sounds exciting but you don’t have anything to break the year up because you have money and you’re not working for anything.

“I used to get jealous when people would say, ‘I can’t wait till Friday.’

“All that a weekend meant for me is ­having people to socialise with while they weren’t working. The rest of the time I was just waiting, feeling lost.

Having a child will change all of that. My days will become full of hard work and not empty like they have been. I will always have someone else ­relying on me which will be a whole new purpose I have never had before.

“The idea of being stood in a school playground in four years time chatting to other parents that I will have something in common with really excites me.”

In 2017 Jane threatened to sue Euromillions for negligence, claiming her win ruined her life, before dropping the case. Organiser Camelot said at the time it had offered her “ongoing support” since her win.

She has called for the age for buying a ticket to be raised from 16 to 18.

Jane said: “My child won’t be buying a lottery tickets until they are at least eighteen. I would never want them to have the experiences I have had.

“I’ve been really sensible with my money, I’ve bought properties and made long-term investments.”

Jane even imagines going into business with her baby. “I want my child to have a work ethic,” she said.

“I want to build a business, ­eventually have my child working with me and I’ll have peace of mind they have a work ethic and can eventually leave it to them.

“I now have a reason to plan for the future, something I never ­needed to do before.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: Jane Park failed to find happiness despite spending a fortune on luxury goods and cosmetic surgery - now she's hoping her baby will give her the contentment she always craved
